author: Michael Roddan
title: Banking stocks rally Aust market
text:
A rally in banking stocks has driven a 1.3 per cent rise in the Australian sharemarket at noon, amid a global equities bounce.
At 12.05pm (AEST), the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index had risen 68.7 points, or 1.34 per cent, to 5183.9, while the broader All Ordinaries lifted 66.3 points, or 1.29 per cent, to 5199.8.
On Wall Street, the key bourses rose more than 2 per cent after a one-day hiatus to mark Labor Day while upwardly revised GDP figures in Europe saw French, German and UK markets rise more than 1 per cent. The moves followed improvements on China's main stock market yesterday.
CMC Markets chief analyst Ric Spooner said the buyers have been firmly in charge over the past 24 hours in a continuation of recent stock market volatility.
"More likely the surge in world share markets over the past 24 hours reflects the fact that many see relative value in current prices. This creates a situation where those who have been waiting on the sidelines are quick to follow once buying starts," he said.
Banking stocks, which had been heavily sold off over recent weeks, were back in vogue today, and were leading the market higher.
Meanwhile, IG market strategist Chris Weston said mining stocks were set to benefit today from strongly positive moves in oil, copper and iron ore futures.
"But the price action in the energy space will get a key look in again today," he said.
"The fact that Oil Search closed at $7.90, and therefore a 3.3 per cent premium to the implied offer from Woodside Petroleum, suggests the market is expecting a fresh bid to emerge at some stage."
Locally, in economic news on Wednesday, the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed home loan approvals during July missed forecasts, increasing 0.3 per cent during the month.
Meanwhile, Westpac-Melbourne Institute survey of consumer sentiment showed economic pessimists far outweighed optimists.
